subject: Investing
title: High-Yield Junk Bonds
description: A quick win: understand High-Yield Junk Bonds.

hook.text: A bond paying 9% when Treasuries pay 4%. Sounds great until you learn why it's called 'junk.'

buildup.text: Junk bonds come from companies with weak credit. Rating agencies score them below BBB, signaling default risk.

discovery.text: Michael Milken built an empire trading junk bonds in the 1980s. He proved high-yield debt could fund growth.

twist.text: In recessions, junk bond default rates spike to 10% or higher. That 9% yield doesn't help if the company goes bankrupt.

climax.text: Junk bonds behave more like stocks than Treasuries. They rise and fall with the economy, not with rates alone.

punchline.text: High yield means high risk. The name 'junk' is a feature, not a bug.

quiz.question: Why are junk bonds called 'high-yield'?
options: They pay higher interest to compensate for higher default risk
They always outperform all other bonds
They are guaranteed by the government
